content.description:
A huge boulder with a short overhanging section.  
  
 Start left hand either meat hook or undercling on a big hold, right hand undercling. Trust some slopers and pull the lip at the prow of the boulder.

54.653662, -99.787599
A pad or two.

A cool problem with all the holds 90 degrees away from the angle you need them to be. 
  
 Starts in a bit of a hole, left hand on a good, flat, sidepull-undercling and right hand on a two finger undercling pocket. Make an enormous move to a crimp up and right. Do some fancy footwork and get your left hand to the lip. Use slopers to get yourself on top.

15 feet uphill from Pinchin' Pennies.
This problem starts in a bit of a hole. Try to jam a folded crashpad down there. One or two other crash pads will easily protect this thing.

A cool overhanging route with cool holds and good quality rock. 
  
 Start with one hand on the bizarre textured knob, and the other in crack. Trend right and climb over the prow of the boulder. 
  
 It is probably worth stacking pads and looking at the holds on the lip/topout (find the fingerlock) before you try this. An uncontrolled fall from anywhere on this route is unacceptable.

On the opposite side of the same boulder as Change is Everything. Accessed by walking through the abandoned looking property and up the hill.
A difficult to protect pointy boulder awaits you if you fall on the low moves. A fall from up high will send you down some ledges and down the hill.

Start underneath the roof on opposing sidepulls, left hand gets a good thumb catch. Go left hand up to the jug and work out to the lip. Mantle. Getting off the ground is probably the hardest part of this one. Note: After repeating this problem a few times, it has become clear that the above defined start does not really suit the rest of the problem. Start one move in (left hand on the jug) for a better problem - v3. 54.653856, -9978754

Walk down the road from the parking area. Just as you reach the first property head uphill towards the cliffs. The boulder is about 50' in. Super low-ball. A crash pad if you want, but it'll make it harder not to dab.

This is the classic line of Herb Lake Landing and reminds me a lot of Bishop's Iron Man. Its a beautiful sloping rail traverse ending with a couple big moves to the lip of the boulder. 
  
 Start matched on the jug on the far left edge of the boulder partially outside the cave. Do some clever footwork to get hands and feet established on the rail and traverse right. Eventually get to the jug and pull the lip.

Uphill from Pinchin' Pennies, in a cave at the base of the cliffs. Coordinates are 54.653827 by -99.787257
3 to 5 crash pads.

Start matched on the lowest, furthest right side of the rail directly under the finishing jug of Tetanus. Make a setup move with the left before launching for the jug.  
  
 There is only one good foot option so this sequence is incredibly hight dependant. There are some holds around the right side of the boulder that could probably make this route go statically. 
  
 Parkour moves shouldn't get climbing grades...

Shares a top out with Tetanus.
One or two pads.

The bouldering at Herb Lake is on good quality lime stone below the cliff band. The routes and movements are good, the landings are not ideal. Tetanus is the stand-out, best problem here, so if you end up at Herb Lake Landing make sure to check that one out. 
  
 Boulder Groupings: 
  
 Fern Area: Pinchin' Pennies, Change is Everything, Fern Seeds. The first area you will find when hiking up from the unused property. 
  
 Tetanus Area: Tetanus and Winkler Dyno. Up the hill from the Fern Area, right at the base of the cliffs. 
  
 Chain of Command Area: Chain of Command. Somewhere between the Fern area and the Ted Taylor and Snowball hiking trail.
